topics.title: Leadership: being loved vs being liked
topics.summary: Ebi explains that effective leadership is about being “loved” (deeply cared for) rather than merely liked, which requires hard conversations and candid feedback grounded in genuine care for the person behind the role.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Ebi’s background (YouTube, Netflix, Uber) and previews the episode’s focus on tactical product vision, communicating vision, improving PM craft, and building product culture.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sidebar (peer groups/personal board of directors) and Jira Product Discovery (prioritization and roadmapping tool for product teams).

topics.title: Why vision matters and core elements
topics.summary: Ebi argues every PM needs a vision at any level and defines key attributes: lofty yet attainable, not constrained by today’s limitations, and grounded in a clear user problem.

topics.title: Examples of strong visions (Uber, Tesla, Mars)
topics.summary: Ebi shares concrete examples: Uber’s future of continuous trips and reduced parking, and Tesla/Musk visions, discussing the tension between inspirational loftiness and attainability.

topics.title: Mission vs vision: practical distinction
topics.summary: Using a Mount Everest analogy, Ebi clarifies mission as the purpose/why and guiding principles, while vision is the vivid picture of the future state when you arrive.

topics.title: Vision artifacts: story frameworks and narratives
topics.summary: Ebi explains that vision can be expressed as a story, introducing a simple narrative template (“once upon a time… one day… because of that… finally…”) to make the future state memorable and motivating.

topics.title: Working backwards: headlines, articles, and screenshots
topics.summary: She describes writing a future TechCrunch/NYT-style headline and article to force clarity, plus visualizing the future via sketches or app-store screenshot mock panels to align teams on the few big rocks.

topics.title: No-designer excuse and low-fidelity visualization
topics.summary: Ebi emphasizes that PMs must tell the story even without design resources—use hand sketches, rectangles, or post-its—then invite designers to refine once the narrative is compelling.

topics.title: Developing vision: empathize, create, evangelize
topics.summary: Ebi introduces a three-part approach: empathize deeply with user problems, create the future-state vision, then evangelize it over time—highlighting patience and resilience against naysayers.

topics.title: Empathize tactics: dogfooding, competitor use, intuition
topics.summary: She outlines practical “understand work”: regularly use your own product and competitors, build product sense from observing great experiences, and avoid over-relying on research as a substitute for judgment.

topics.title: Top 10 problems doc and stakeholder inputs
topics.summary: Ebi describes a living “top 10 things you should know” problems document (qual + quant + tech debt) and a structured way to collect stakeholder perspectives using the same template to converge on shared priorities.

topics.title: Strategy sessions: insights, strategy, big rocks
topics.summary: She explains a 2–3 day narrative-structured strategy offsite: day 1 insights/teardowns, day 2 prioritization strategy, day 3 big rocks—run with a cross-functional core (PM/Eng/Design/Research, plus data as needed).

topics.title: Evangelizing vision: team, stakeholders, leadership
topics.summary: Ebi shares a concentric-circles rollout: align the full team first with repeatable storytelling and a commentable living doc, then stakeholders, then senior leadership—using the process to show people they were heard.
